''Stalking Strangers' DNA'' (''The DNA Age'' series, front page, April 2) states that the law views DNA from discarded cigarettes, drinking cups and so on to be abandoned property.
In fact, the courts have not reached a clear decision on whether people have an expectation of privacy over their DNA, which they are continuously but not intentionally shedding.

How many of us would care whether anyone, without our consent, could violate our privacy by probing into our genome? And if that probing without a court warrant is legal, what is the value of all the genetic privacy laws and laws against genetic discrimination that have been enacted by many states, while a federal bill is pending in Congress?
The writer is a visiting scholar in the department of sociomedical sciences, Columbia University.
